awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nonlinear Dynamics and Wave Propagation through Phononic Tunneling Junctions based on Classical and Quantum Mechanical Bistable Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support research that will contribute new knowledge related to nonlinear dynamics and wave propagation through classical and quantum mechanical bistable structures, which is critical for phononic quantum computing. Current state-of-the-art quantum computers complete complex computations at unprecedented speeds; however, they require very low operating temperatures, limiting their practical use. Further, the current lack of a well-established tunneling junction capable of processing phononic quantum information limits progress in phononic quantum computing. Bistable structures are a promising approach for the realization of a mechanical tunneling junction because, at the nanoscale, their energy barrier approaches the energy of a single phonon. This award supports fundamental research to provide the knowledge regarding the nonlinear dynamics of classical and quantum mechanical bistable structures needed for the development of these novel tunneling junctions. These tunneling junctions will be used for processing and computing of quantum information carried by single phonons and will dramatically advance the technology of room-temperature quantum computing. This capability will advance knowledge in dynamics, quantum physics, nanoscience, and nanofabrication. This research will benefit U.S. society due to the critical need for high performance computing in science, defense and industry. This multi-disciplinary research will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in science and engineering and positively impact STEM education.

The objective of this research is to investigate the fundamental nonlinear dynamics and wave transmission through mechanical bistable structures in classical and quantum regimes for their potential application as mechanical tunneling junctions. Such mechanical tunneling junctions will process quantum bits, which is critical to quantum computing platforms using phonons. The central hypothesis of this research is that a nanoscale bistable structure can transmit mechanical waves (phonons) with a high enough transmission efficiency to act as a quantum tunneling junction if the structure is driven by nonlinear and contactless conservative interactions. This hypothesis will be tested in both classical and quantum regimes by 1) characterizing the snap-though dynamics and wave transmission of macroscale bistable elements with contact interactions and nonlinear conservative (contactless) interactions, 2) evaluating the mechanical wave (phonon) transmission efficiency through a micro-scale structure theoretically and experimentally, and 3) demonstrating the quantum dynamics of phonon tunneling through mechanical tunneling junction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on: (1) analytical characterization of bistable behavior; (2) macroscopic analysis of nonlinear bistable systems; (3) investigation of interwell/intra-well dynamics under varying velocities; (4) energy threshold analysis during intra-to-interwell transitions; and (5) exploration of coupled bistable system chains.

The fundamental dynamics of a continuous bistable beam under sinusoidal vibro-impact excitation were systematically investigated. Experimental and computational analyses under a various of mechainical buckling conditions revealed complex nonlinear phenomena with strong parametric dependence. Crucially, the output from this project  establishes that higher-order modal components are essential for accurate modeling of bistable beam behavior near metastable configurations.

This project examines nonreciprocal dynamics in a magnetically coupled bistable-monostable pendulum system. As the result of this project, non-reciprocal dynamics were examined in a magnetically coupled bistable-monostable pendulum system. A dipole-interaction dynamical model was developed to replicate experimentally observed amplitude-dependent responses. Energy injection via bistable element displacement generated two regimes: low-amplitude intrawell oscillations with limited energy transmission, and suprathreshold interwell motion enabling directional energy transfer. System asymmetry and nonlinear coupling were identified as drivers of emergent non-reciprocity, validated through parametric studies. Numerical simulations revealed diode-like transmission characteristics, suggesting applications in mechanical metamaterials and wave-based signal processing.

By modifying some control parameter, i.e. the excitation velocity, V, this project discovered that some of bifurcations occurs as the experimented system shifts between interwell and intrawell responses. A period four intrawell response with five impacts per cycle is observed while the mass moves within the first energy well. As velocity increases, the mass is able to escape the first energy well. The escape occurs only during the transient response and quickly converges back to the period-eight intrawell response, forming a transient interwell response. This initial overshoot implies that this transition to interwell responses is dependent on initial conditions. The variety of impacts that the mass experiences as it converges to steady-state. As velocity continues to increase, the mass travels continuously between energy wells, which is known as the continuous interwell responses with a period-one response and a single impact per cycle. At a certain velocity, the mass can escape the first equilibrium and remain in the second equilibrium

This project demonstrate the exhibition of  a notch on the energy perspective for nonlinear bistable systems with continuously pulsed energy input. The notch is also visible in the theoretical results obtained. This notch is caused by the combined effect of a nonlinear resonance of the steady-state response of the bistable system and an overshoot in its transient response. At very low excitation amplitude, a maximum in the steady-state response is observed. As the shaker velocity amplitude is increased, the curve of the maximum displacement of the mass veers toward the left due to the softening of the bistable spring, such that two stable branches and one stable branch are predicted for period-one solutions. The stable branch of low energy corresponds to impacts at a phase of approximately −0.25 cycles (i.e., minimum shaker displacement) while the branch of high energy corresponds to impacts at approximately 0.25 cycles (maximum shaker displacement). The convergence of responses to the low energy period-one orbit and to the high energy period-one orbit, respectively. However, the initial transient response tends to overshoot the steady-state solution in all cases for the initial conditions used in the simulations. In certain cases, this overshoot is sufficient to overcome the energy barrier of the bistable spring, such that a transient interwell response with convergence to the second equilibrium is observed.

The intellectual significance of this project lies in its unified exploration of bistable systems under mechanical wave excitation, bridging classical nonlinear dynamics with quantum-scale phenomena. By developing multi-physics models that integrate air viscosity, nanomechanical Casimir forces, and quantum tunneling probabilities, this research advances high-fidelity predictions of wave propagation through bistable "gates" across scales. At macroscopic levels, it resolves snap-through dynamics in pre-buckled beams under vibro-impact loading, while microscale extensions probe phonon tunneling in carbon-nanotube-based double-well potentials. This dual-scale framework not only refines classical theories of energy transmission but also establishes foundational principles for phononic quantum computing, where engineered bistable junctions could enable controlled phonon-mediated information processing. The synergy of computational models and experimental validation paves the way for mechanically tunable quantum-classical interfaces, positioning bistable systems as transformative platforms for next-generation sensing, computing, and metamaterial technologies.

In general, this project provides critical insights into bistable system dynamics across multiple scales, advancing modeling methodologies for vibro-impact systems and informing the development of nonlinear metamaterials. The demonstrated fabrication framework and macroscopic validation approach establish foundational protocols for miniaturized bistable device implementation.
